node.title: COVID, Inflation and Everyday Bills Top List of Concerns for Americans, Poll Finds
node.description: As prices rise, the number of Americans who say that paying for groceries is easy has declined by 13 percentage points over the past two years.

node.title: Photo Shows Kellogg's Products Out of Stock as Employees Prolong Strike
node.description: About 1,400 Kellogg's staff at plants in Battle Creek, Michigan, Omaha, Nebraska, Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and Memphis, Tennessee, are on strike.

node.title: U.K. Joins U.S., Australia Boycott of Beijing Olympics, Still Sending Athletes to Compete
node.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the U.K. will join in the diplomatic boycott, but he doesn't support boycotts involving athletes and they may compete.

node.title: Who Is Janette Miller? Appraiser Sued by Black Couple Who Accuse Her of Lowballing Them
node.description: Tenisha Tate-Austin and Paul Austin filed a lawsuit after a second appraisal of their California home produced a valuation almost half a million dollars higher than Miller's estimate.

node.title: "Mr. Optimist": Michael J. Fox reflects 30 years after Parkinson's diagnosis
node.description: Michael J. Fox was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease​ when he was 29 years old.

node.title: Unvaccinated Austrians to Remain in Lockdown, Have Limits On Why They Can Leave Home
node.description: The current lockdown permits people to leave their homes only for reasons like grocery shopping, going to medical appointments and exercising.

node.title: People Can't Quite Believe McDonald's Used to Have Branded Ashtrays for Smoking Indoors
node.description: "A quarter-pounder, fries, shake, and a few cigarettes is probably the best last meal you could order."

node.title: Better CEO apologizes for firing 900 workers via Zoom call
node.description: Vishal Garg said he is sorry about mass firing, saying he failed to show "respect and appreciation" for workers.

node.title: The number of people quitting jobs remained near a record in October as openings increased.
node.description: The Labor Department said that 4.2 million people quit their jobs last month, a decline of about 205,000 from September but still close to a record high.

node.title: Jan. 6 Rally Planner to Tell House Panel He Played No Role in Violence
node.description: Ali Alexander, a right-wing activist who helped organize the gathering that drew Trump supporters to Washington on Jan. 6, is cooperating with the committee investigating the riot.

node.title: Scientists React to Study on Viagra As Potential Alzheimer's Treatment: 'Very Intriguing'
node.description: A study has found that Viagra—commonly prescribed to men with erectile dysfunction—could be a potential candidate for treating the degenerative disease.

node.title: Elderly woman dies in floodwaters in Brisbane's south-west
node.description: A 75-year-old Taringa woman dies in floodwaters in Brisbane's outer-west after her car was washed away on Wednesday afternoon.

node.title: "Bizarre" coral reef sounds offer hope of recovery after destruction
node.description: Scientists say there's now hope that reefs previously destroyed by fishermen using explosives to kill massive amounts of fish can be restored.

node.title: Germany bids Angela Merkel farewell as Olaf Scholz takes power
node.description: The man elected to take the helm of Europe's biggest economy as the new German Chancellor is a social democrat, but he'll share power with two other parties.

node.title: Chanel Celebrates Craft, and Cardigans
node.description: The brand’s annual Métiers d’Art show went on, despite controversy.

node.title: Meg Stalter Rejoices With Dolly Parton and a Loyal Chihuahua
node.description: The comedian talks about banishing the worst of 2021 in Amazon’s “Yearly Departed,” while celebrating the best in real life.

node.title: Angela Merkel’s Political Life in Pictures: The End of an Era
node.description: Images from the former chancellor’s 16 years leading Germany, and from her life before.

node.title: Video Shows 'Weirdest Tardigrade Ever' Named After Kramer From 'Seinfeld'
node.description: James Weiss, who studies microbes, told Newsweek the tiny animal was "the clumsiest tardigrade" he had ever seen.

node.title: Patrick Orlando, Bankroller of Donald Trump's Truth Social, Severs China Connections
node.description: Patrick Orlando holds the CEO post of a Wuhan-based shell company that filed for delisting on Monday.

node.title: Democrats Warn Texas is Next Target for Disinformation Aimed at Latinos
node.description: "It's clear that 2020 was a wakeup call and Florida was a warning," San-Antonio based Democratic strategist Joaquin Guerra told Newsweek.

node.title: As Overdose Deaths Soar, White House Announces Harm Reduction Program
node.description: "It's the drug supply that's killing people, not their addictions," Dr. Sheila Vakharia told Newsweek. "Addiction doesn't have to result in death. It's when you're using a toxic drug supply that this death is more likely."

node.title: 'Mistaken identity': French authorities admit error in arrest of Saudi man they linked to Jamal Khashoggi's murder
node.description: French authorities are forced to admit they made an error and release a Saudi man they arrested over suspected involvement in the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

node.title: Video of Matt Gaetz, Marjorie Taylor Greene Being Asked About Jan. 6 Officers Goes Viral
node.description: The remark was made as four GOP lawmakers—Greene and Gaetz, plus Paul Gosar and Louie Gohmert—held a press conference claiming that January 6 defendants were being treated unfairly.

node.title: Stacey Abrams Says Money and Peer Pressure Can Hold Politicians Accountable
node.description: Abrams' comments came from upcoming interview from three-time NBA champion Stephen Curry's new podcast Fifteen Minutes from Home.

node.title: House Hunting in Greece: Seaside Splendor on Tinos Isle for $1.8 Million
node.description: Greeks increasingly see real estate as a safer investment than currencies or commodities, and ‘people are buying like there’s no tomorrow.’

node.title: What Is the Staples Center in Los Angeles Changing Its Name To?
node.description: The historic Los Angeles venue will get an official new name this Christmas, following one of the biggest naming deals in sports history.

node.title: Better CEO Vishal Garg 'Sorry' After Mass Firing Over Zoom: 'I Blundered the Execution'
node.description: "I own the decision to do the layoffs, but in communicating it, I blundered the execution. In doing so, I embarrassed you," Vishal Garg wrote in a letter.

node.title: Blaze forces closure of campgrounds, wineries and tourist attractions in Margaret River region
node.description: Campgrounds, wineries and caves are evacuated as a bushfire threatens lives and homes around the Boranup Forest near Margaret River in WA's South West.

node.title: France releases man held as possible suspect in Khashoggi murder
node.description: Khalid Alotaibi, 33, is wanted by Turkey to face justice over the brutal killing, but the man detained in Paris wasn't him.

node.title: California’s Reparations Task Force Meets Again
node.description: The first-in-the-nation effort is tackling fraught questions about who deserves payment and how much.
